newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria parliament approves grain import deal.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria parliament approves grain import deal.

text.p: Bulgaria's beleaguered parliament on Thursday approved a $35 million grain import deal under a U.S. government credit programme in a bid to resolve an acute grain crisis, state agency BTA said.
"Parliament decided to authorise the cabinet to give the bank guarantees required for the deal," said BTA.

The opposition is boycotting parliament, which protesters ransacked on Friday after the ruling Socialists refused to agree on early elections. On Wednesday, the Socialists and opposition agreed to start negotiations.
Bulgaria, facing an acute grain shortage due to excessive exports in 1995, had a poor harvest last year and will have to import large quantities of wheat.
Parliament's agricultural committee said stocks of wheat for bread and fodder would last until end-January.

Bulgaria's wheat stocks stood at 130,000 tonnes five months ago, while domestic wheat consumption is 500,000 tonnes a year. The agriculture ministry has declined to release updated grain supply figures since then.

In October Bulgaria lost a $25 million credit guarantee for the import of 120,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat after Bulbank refused to confirm the credit line on the grounds that the conditions were unfavourable. -- Elisaveta Konstantinova, Sofia Newsroom +359-2-84561
